title: Fire safety at home: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fire Safety at Home**

\n\n

**Smoke Alarms or Detectors**

Smoke alarms or detectors work even when you cannot smell smoke. Tips for proper use include:

*   Install them in hallways, in or near all sleeping areas, the kitchen, and garage.
*   Test them once a month. Change the batteries regularly. Another option is an alarm with a 10-year battery.
*   Dust or vacuum over the smoke alarm as needed.

\n\n

**Using a Fire Extinguisher**

Using a fire extinguisher can put out a small fire to keep it from getting out of control. Tips for use include:

*   Keep fire extinguishers in handy locations, at least one on each level of your home.
*   Be sure to have a fire extinguisher in your kitchen and one in your garage.
*   Know how to use a fire extinguisher. Teach everyone in your family how to use one, too. In an emergency, you must be able to act fast.

\n\n

**Escaping Fires**

Fires can be loud, burn fast, and produce a lot of smoke. It is a good idea for everyone to know how to get out of their home quickly if one occurs.

*   Set up fire escape routes from every room in your house. It is best to have 2 ways to get out of each room, since one of the ways may be blocked by smoke or fire.
*   Have twice-a-year fire drills to practice escaping.
*   Teach family members what to do in case of a fire.

\n\n

**Smoke Rises During a Fire**

Smoke rises during a fire. So the safest place to be when escaping is down low to the ground.

\n\n

**Exiting Through a Door**

Exiting through a door is best, when possible. Always feel the door starting at the bottom and work upward before opening it. If the door is hot, there may be fire on the other side.

\n\n

**Have a Safe Spot Planned Ahead of Time**

Have a safe spot planned ahead of time for everyone to meet outside after escape.

\n\n

**Never Go Back Inside for Anything**

Never go back inside for anything. Stay outside.

\n\n

**Preventing Fires**

To prevent fires:

*   Do not smoke in bed.
*   Keep matches and other flammable materials out of reach of children.
*   Never leave a burning candle or fireplace unattended. Do not stand too close to the fire.
*   Never put clothes or anything else over a lamp or heater.
*   Make sure household wiring is up-to-date.
*   Unplug appliances such as heating pads and electric blankets when they are not in use.
*   Store flammable materials away from heat sources, water heaters, and open-flame space heaters.
*   When cooking or grilling, do not leave the stove or grill unattended.
*   Be sure to close the valve on a propane cylinder tank when it is not in use. Know how to store the tank safely.

\n\n

**Teaching Children About Fires**

Teach children about fires. Explain how they are accidentally started and how to prevent them. Children should understand the following:

*   Do not touch or get close to radiators or heaters.
*   Never stand close to the fireplace or wood stove.
*   Do not touch matches, lighters, or candles. Tell an adult right away if you see any of these items.
*   Do not cook without asking an adult first.
*   Never play with electrical cords or stick anything into a socket.

\n\n

**Children's Sleepwear**

Children's sleepwear should be snug-fitting and specifically labeled as flame-resistant. Using other clothing, including loose-fitting garments, increases the risk for severe burns if these items catch fire.

\n\n

**Fireworks**

Do not allow children to handle or play with fireworks. Many places in the United States do not permit lighting fireworks in residential areas. Go to public displays if your family wants to enjoy fireworks.

\n\n

**Oxygen Therapy**

If oxygen therapy is being used in your home, teach everyone in the family about oxygen safety to prevent fires.

---

**Fire Safety at Home**

As a parent, it's natural to want to protect your family from harm. One of the most important steps you can take is to ensure your home is fire-safe. In this article, we'll explore the importance of fire safety and provide tips on how to prevent fires and escape in case of an emergency.

**Smoke Alarms or Detectors**

Smoke alarms or detectors are a crucial part of any fire safety plan. They work even when you can't smell smoke, and proper use is key:

* Install them in hallways, near sleeping areas, the kitchen, and garage.
* Test them once a month and change batteries regularly.
* Consider an alarm with a 10-year battery.

**Using a Fire Extinguisher**

A fire extinguisher can put out small fires before they get out of control. To use one effectively:

* Keep fire extinguishers in handy locations, at least one on each level of your home.
* Have one in the kitchen and garage.
* Know how to use it, and teach everyone in your family.

**Escaping Fires**

Fires can be loud, burn fast, and produce a lot of smoke. It's essential for everyone in the household to know how to escape quickly:

* Set up fire escape routes from every room, with at least two ways out.
* Practice escaping twice a year through fire drills.
* Teach family members what to do in case of a fire.

**Smoke Rises**

When escaping a fire, remember that smoke rises. The safest place to be is down low to the ground:

* Exiting through a door is best when possible.
* Always feel the door starting at the bottom and work upward before opening it.
* If the door is hot, there may be fire on the other side.

**Have a Safe Spot**

Plan ahead of time for everyone to meet outside after escaping. Never go back inside for anything  stay outside!

**Preventing Fires**

To prevent fires:

* Don't smoke in bed.
* Keep matches and flammable materials out of reach of children.
* Never leave a burning candle or fireplace unattended.
* Make sure household wiring is up-to-date.
* Unplug appliances when not in use.

**Teaching Children About Fire Safety**

Teach children about fire safety by explaining how fires are accidentally started and how to prevent them. They should understand:

* Don't touch radiators or heaters.
* Never stand close to the fireplace or wood stove.
* Don't touch matches, lighters, or candles.
* Don't cook without asking an adult first.

**Additional Tips**

* Store flammable materials away from heat sources and water heaters.
* Be sure to close the valve on a propane cylinder tank when not in use.
* Teach children about oxygen safety if using oxygen therapy at home.

By following these tips, you can help create a fire-safe environment for your family. Remember to stay vigilant and regularly review your fire safety plan to ensure everyone is prepared in case of an emergency.

---

**Fire Safety at Home**

As a parent, it's essential to teach your children about fire safety to prevent accidental fires in the home. Here are some key points to discuss with your kids:

*   **Children's sleepwear**: Make sure they wear snug-fitting, flame-resistant clothing to reduce the risk of severe burns.
*   **Fireworks**: Never let children handle or play with fireworks. Instead, attend public displays where professionals will handle the fireworks safely.
*   **Oxygen therapy**: If someone in your household uses oxygen therapy, educate everyone about oxygen safety to prevent fires.

By following these simple tips, you can significantly reduce the risk of accidental fires in your home and keep your family safe.

title: First Aid: MedlinePlus
content:
**First Aid: MedlinePlus (Part 1/2)**

Accidents happen. Someone chokes on an ice cube or gets stung by a bee. It is important to know when to call 911 -- it is for life-threatening emergencies. While waiting for help to arrive, you may be able to save someone's life. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is for people whose hearts or breathing has stopped and the Heimlich maneuver is for people who are choking.

You can also learn to handle common injuries and wounds. Cuts and scrapes, for example, should be rinsed with cool water. To stop bleeding, apply firm but gentle pressure, using gauze. If blood soaks through, add more gauze, keeping the first layer in place. Continue to apply pressure.

It is important to have a first aid kit available. Keep one at home and one in your car. It should include a first-aid guide. Read the guide to learn how to use the items, so you are ready in case an emergency happens.

title: First aid kit: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**First Aid Kit**

You should make sure that you and your family are prepared to treat common symptoms, injuries, and emergencies. By planning ahead, you can create a well-stocked home first aid kit. Keep all of your supplies in one location so you know exactly where they are when you need them.

**Bandages and Dressings:**

* Adhesive bandages (Band-Aid or similar brand); assorted sizes
* Aluminum finger splints
* Elastic (ACE) bandage for wrapping wrist, ankle, knee, and elbow injuries
* Eye shield, pads, and bandages
* Latex or non-latex gloves to reduce contamination risk
* Sterile gauze pads, non-stick (Adaptic-type, petrolatum or other) gauze and adhesive tape
* Triangular bandage for wrapping injuries and making an arm sling

**Home Health Equipment:**

* Blue baby bulb or turkey baster suction device
* Disposable, instant ice bags
* Face mask to reduce wound contamination risk

**First-Aid Manual, Hand Sanitizer, and Miscellaneous Supplies:**

* First-aid manual
* Hand sanitizer
* Latex or non-latex gloves to reduce contamination risk
* Save-A-Tooth storage device in case a tooth is broken or knocked out; contains a travel case and salt solution
* Sterile cotton balls
* Sterile cotton-tipped swabs
* Syringe, medicine cup, or medicine spoon for giving specific doses of medicine
* Thermometer
* Tweezers, to remove ticks and small splinters

**Medicine for Cuts and Injuries:**

* Antiseptic solution or wipes, such as hydrogen peroxide, povidone-iodine, or chlorhexidine
* Antibiotic ointment, such as bacitracin, polysporin, or mupirocin
* Sterile eyewash, such as contact lens saline solution
* Calamine lotion for stings or poison ivy
* Hydrocortisone cream, ointment, or lotion for itching

Be sure to check your kit regularly. Replace any supplies that are getting low or have expired.

Other supplies may be included in a first aid kit. This depends on the area in which you plan to spend time.

title: Fish tapeworm infection: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fish Tapeworm Infection**

_Fish tapeworm infection is an intestinal infection with a parasite found in fish._

**Causes**

The fish tapeworm (Diphyllobothrium latum) is the largest parasite that infects humans. Humans become infected when they eat raw or undercooked freshwater fish that contain fish tapeworm cysts.

The infection is seen in many areas where humans eat uncooked or undercooked freshwater fish from rivers or lakes, including:

* Africa
* Eastern Europe
* North and South America
* Scandinavia
* Some Asian countries

**Symptoms**

Most people who are infected have no symptoms. If symptoms do occur, they may include:

* Abdominal discomfort or pain
* Diarrhea
* Weakness
* Weight loss

**Exams and Tests**

People who are infected sometimes pass segments of worm in their stools. These segments can be seen in the stool.

Tests may include:

* Complete blood count, including differential
* Blood tests to determine the cause of anemia, if present
* Vitamin B12 level
* Stool exam for worm eggs and parasites

**Treatment**

You will receive medicines to fight the parasites. You take these medicines by mouth, usually in a single dose.

The drug of choice for tapeworm infections is praziquantel. Niclosamide can also be used. If needed, your health care provider will prescribe vitamin B12 injections or supplements to treat vitamin B12 deficiency and anemia.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Fish tapeworms can be treated with a single treatment dose. There are no lasting effects.

**Possible Complications**

Untreated, fish tapeworm infection may cause the following:

* Anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency (megaloblastic anemia)
* Intestinal blockage (rare)

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if:

* You have noticed a worm or segments of a worm in your stool
* You have symptoms of anemia
* Any family members are diagnosed with a fish tapeworm infection

**Prevention**

Measures you can take to prevent tapeworm infection include:

* Do not eat raw or undercooked fish.
* Cook fish at 145F (63C) for at least 4 minutes. Use a food thermometer to measure the thickest part of the fish.
* Freeze fish at -4F (-20C) or below for 7 days, or at -31F (-35C) or below for 15 hours.

**Alternative Names**

Diphyllobothriasis

---

**Fish Tapeworm Infection**

The fish tapeworm (Diphyllobothrium latum) is the largest parasite that infects humans. Humans become infected when they eat raw or undercooked freshwater fish that contain fish tapeworm cysts.

**Causes and Geographic Distribution**

The infection is seen in many areas where humans eat uncooked or undercooked freshwater fish from rivers or lakes, including:

* Africa
* Eastern Europe
* North and South America
* Scandinavia
* Some Asian countries

After a person has eaten infected fish, the worm larva begins to grow in the intestine. Larvae are fully grown in 3 to 6 weeks. The adult worm, which is segmented, attaches to the wall of the intestine. The tapeworm may reach a length of 30 feet (9 meters). Eggs are formed in each segment of the worm and are passed in the stool. Sometimes, parts of the worm may also be passed in the stool.

The tapeworm absorbs the nutrition from food that the infected person eats. This may lead to vitamin B12 deficiency and anemia.

**Symptoms**

Most people who are infected have no symptoms. If symptoms do occur, they may include:

* Abdominal discomfort or pain
* Diarrhea
* Weakness
* Weight loss

**Exams and Tests**

People who are infected sometimes pass segments of worm in their stools. These segments can be seen in the stool.

Tests may include:

* Complete blood count, including differential
* Blood tests to determine the cause of anemia, if present
* Vitamin B12 level
* Stool exam for worm eggs and parasites

**Treatment**

You will receive medicines to fight the parasites. You take these medicines by mouth, usually in a single dose.

The drug of choice for tapeworm infections is praziquantel. Niclosamide can also be used. If needed, your health care provider will prescribe vitamin B12 injections or supplements to treat vitamin B12 deficiency and anemia.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Fish tapeworms can be treated with a single treatment dose. There are no lasting effects.

**Possible Complications**

Untreated, fish tapeworm infection may cause the following:

* Anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency (megaloblastic anemia)
* Intestinal blockage (rare)

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if:

* You have noticed a worm or segments of a worm in your stool
* You have symptoms of anemia
* Any family members are diagnosed with a fish tapeworm infection

**Prevention**

Measures you can take to prevent tapeworm infection include:

* Do not eat raw or undercooked fish.
* Cook fish at 145F (63C) for at least 4 minutes. Use a food thermometer to measure the thickest part of the fish.
* Freeze fish at -4F (-20C) or below for 7 days, or at -31F (-35C) or below for 15 hours.

**Alternative Names**

Diphyllobothriasis

---

**Fish Tapeworm Infection**

\n\n

**What is a fish tapeworm infection?**

A fish tapeworm infection, also known as diphyllobothriasis, is a parasitic infection caused by the fish tapeworm (Diphyllobothrium spp.). This type of infection is usually acquired through the consumption of raw or undercooked fish that contains the parasite.

\n\n

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of a fish tapeworm infection can vary depending on the severity of the infection. Some common symptoms include:

*   Fatigue
*   Weight loss
*   Abdominal pain
*   Diarrhea
*   Nausea and vomiting

In severe cases, the infection can cause neurological problems, such as numbness or tingling in the hands and feet.

\n\n

**Causes**

Fish tapeworm infections are typically acquired through the consumption of raw or undercooked fish that contains the parasite. The most common source of infection is the consumption of raw or pickled herring.

\n\n

**Risk Factors**

Certain individuals are at a higher risk of developing a fish tapeworm infection, including:

*   People who consume raw or undercooked fish regularly
*   Individuals who live in areas where the parasite is common
*   Those with weakened immune systems

\n\n

**Diagnosis**

The diagnosis of a fish tapeworm infection typically involves a combination of clinical evaluation and laboratory tests. These may include:

*   Physical examination
*   Laboratory tests to detect the presence of the parasite or its eggs in stool samples
*   Imaging studies, such as X-rays or CT scans, to evaluate any potential complications

\n\n

**Treatment**

The treatment of a fish tapeworm infection usually involves antiparasitic medication. In some cases, hospitalization may be necessary to manage any potential complications.

\n\n

**Prevention**

To prevent a fish tapeworm infection, it is essential to handle and cook fish properly. This includes:

*   Freezing the fish at 0F (-18C) for a certain period to kill the parasite
*   Cooking the fish thoroughly before consumption
*   Avoiding the consumption of raw or undercooked fish

By taking these precautions, individuals can significantly reduce their risk of developing a fish tapeworm infection.

title: Fish-eye disease: MedlinePlus Genetics
content:
**Fish-eye disease**

\n\n

**Description**

Fish-eye disease, also called partial LCAT deficiency, is a disorder that causes the clear front surface of the eyes (the corneas) to gradually become cloudy. The cloudiness, which generally first appears in adolescence or early adulthood, consists of small grayish dots of cholesterol (opacities) distributed across the corneas. Cholesterol is a waxy, fat-like substance that is produced in the body and obtained from foods that come from animals; it aids in many functions of the body but can become harmful in excessive amounts. As fish-eye disease progresses, the corneal cloudiness worsens and can lead to severely impaired vision.

\n\n

**Frequency**

Fish-eye disease is a rare disorder. Approximately 30 cases have been reported in the medical literature.

\n\n

**Causes**

Fish-eye disease is caused by mutations in the LCAT gene. This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT). The LCAT enzyme plays a role in removing cholesterol from the blood and tissues by helping it attach to molecules called lipoproteins, which carry it to the liver. Once in the liver, the cholesterol is redistributed to other tissues or removed from the body. The enzyme has two major functions, called alpha- and beta-LCAT activity. Alpha-LCAT activity helps attach cholesterol to a lipoprotein called high-density lipoprotein (HDL). Beta-LCAT activity helps attach cholesterol to other lipoproteins called very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

LCAT gene mutations that cause fish-eye disease impair alpha-LCAT activity, reducing the enzyme's ability to attach cholesterol to HDL. Impairment of this mechanism for reducing cholesterol in the body leads to cholesterol-containing opacities in the corneas. It is not known why the cholesterol deposits affect only the corneas in this disorder.

\n\n

**Inheritance**

Fish-eye disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are needed to develop the condition.

---

**Fish-eye disease**

\n\n

*   **What is Fish-eye disease?**
    Fish-eye disease, also known as LCAT deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by corneal opacities due to cholesterol-containing deposits in the corneas.

\n\n

*   **Causes and symptoms**
    The condition arises from mutations in the LCAT gene, which affects the production of lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase. This enzyme plays a crucial role in reducing cholesterol levels in the body by converting it into a form that can be easily excreted. In Fish-eye disease, this mechanism is impaired, leading to cholesterol deposits in the corneas.

\n\n

*   **Inheritance pattern**
    Fish-eye disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with this condition typically do not show signs and symptoms, as they are carriers of one mutated copy of the gene.

\n\n

*   **Other names for the condition**
    Fish-eye disease is also known by other names, including Alpha-LCAT deficiency, Alpha-lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency, Dyslipoproteinemic corneal dystrophy, FED (LCATA deficiency), and Partial LCAT deficiency.

\n\n

*   **Additional information & resources**
    For those affected by Fish-eye disease or their families, there are various resources available for genetic testing, patient support, and advocacy. These include the Genetic Testing Registry, the Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center, the National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD), ClinicalTrials.gov, and the Catalog of Genes and Diseases from OMIM.

\n\n

*   **References**
    For further understanding of Fish-eye disease, references to scientific articles on PubMed provide valuable insights into the molecular basis of the condition. These studies have shed light on the structural differences between wild-type and mutant LCAT enzymes, as well as the relationship between very low levels of HDL cholesterol and atherosclerosis in individuals with LCAT deficiency.

---

**Fish-eye disease**

**A rare case of fish-eye disease presenting at age 75 years**

In a remarkable case, a 75-year-old individual was found to be suffering from fish-eye disease, a condition caused by mutations in the LCAT gene. This double heterozygote had two defined and new mutations affecting the structure and expression of the LCAT protein.

**Related Health Topics**

* Corneal Disorders
* Genetic Disorders

title: Fishhook removal: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fishhook Removal**

This article discusses how to remove a fishhook that is stuck in the skin.

**Causes**

Fishing accidents are the most common cause of fishhooks stuck in the skin.

**Symptoms**

A fishhook stuck in the skin can cause:

* Pain
* Localized swelling
* Bleeding

**First Aid**

If the barb of the hook has not entered the skin, pull the tip of the hook out in the opposite direction it went in. Otherwise, you can use one of the following ways to remove a hook that is superficially (not deeply) embedded just beneath the skin.

**Fish Line Method**

1. Wash your hands with soap and water or use a disinfecting solution.
2. Wash the skin surrounding the hook.
3. Put a loop of fish line or string through the bend of the fishhook so that a quick jerk can be applied and the hook can be pulled out straight backward, directly in line with the shaft of the hook.
4. Holding onto the shaft, push the hook slightly downwards and inwards (away from the barb) so as to disengage the barb.
5. Holding this pressure constant to keep the barb disengaged, give a quick jerk on the fish line and the hook will pop out.
6. Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water. Apply a loose, sterile dressing. Do not close the wound with tape. Doing so can increase the chance of infection.
7. Watch the skin for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pain, or drainage.

**Wire Cutting Method**

1. Wash your hands with soap and water or disinfecting solution. Then wash the skin surrounding the hook.
2. If the tip of the hook lies near the surface of the skin, advance the tip up and through the skin. Then cut it off just behind the barb with wire cutters. Remove the rest of the hook by pulling it back through the way it entered.
3. Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water. Apply a loose sterile dressing and apply antibiotic ointment. Do not close the wound with tape. Doing so can increase the chance of infection.
4. Watch skin for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pain, or drainage.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

The main advantage to getting medical help for any fishhook injury is that it can be removed under local anesthesia. This means before the hook is removed, your health care provider numbs the area with medicine.

Contact your provider if:

* You have a fishhook injury and your tetanus immunization is not up to date (or if you are unsure)
* After the fishhook is removed, the area starts to show signs of infection, such as increasing redness, swelling, pain, or drainage

---

**Fishhook Removal**

If you've got a fishhook stuck in your skin, don't panic! With the right techniques and precautions, you can remove it safely. But first, make sure you're up to date on your tetanus immunization - get a booster shot every 10 years.

**Causes**

Fishing accidents are the most common cause of fishhooks stuck in the skin.

**Symptoms**

A fishhook stuck in the skin can cause:

* Pain
* Localized swelling
* Bleeding

**First Aid**

If the barb of the hook has not entered the skin, pull the tip of the hook out in the opposite direction it went in. Otherwise, you can use one of the following ways to remove a hook that is superficially (not deeply) embedded just beneath the skin.

**Fish Line Method**

1. Wash your hands with soap and water or disinfecting solution.
2. Put a loop of fish line or string through the bend of the fishhook so that a quick jerk can be applied and the hook can be pulled out straight backward, directly in line with the shaft of the hook.
3. Holding onto the shaft, push the hook slightly downwards and inwards (away from the barb) so as to disengage the barb.
4. Holding this pressure constant to keep the barb disengaged, give a quick jerk on the fish line and the hook will pop out.

**Wire Cutting Method**

1. Wash your hands with soap and water or disinfecting solution.
2. If the tip of the hook lies near the surface of the skin, advance the tip up and through the skin. Then cut it off just behind the barb with wire cutters. Remove the rest of the hook by pulling it back through the way it entered.

**Important Precautions**

Do not use any of these methods if the hook is stuck deeply in the skin, or in a joint or tendon, or located in or near an eye, eyelid, or artery. Get medical help right away.

A fishhook in the eye is a medical emergency, and you should go to the nearest emergency room right away. The injured person should lie down with the head slightly raised. They should not move the eye, and the eye should be protected from further injury.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if:

* You have a fishhook injury and your tetanus immunization is not up to date (or if you are unsure)
* After the fishhook is removed, the area starts to show signs of infection, such as increasing redness, swelling, pain, or drainage

---

**Fishhook Removal**

**Prevention is Key**

To avoid fishhook injuries, keep a safe distance from others while fishing, especially when casting. Also, make sure you have electrician's pliers with a wire-cutting blade and disinfecting solution in your tackle box.

Additionally, ensure you are up-to-date on your tetanus immunization (vaccine). You should get a booster shot every 10 years.

**Contact Your Provider If:**

You have a fishhook injury and your tetanus immunization is not up to date (or if you are unsure)
After the fishhook is removed, the area starts to show signs of infection, such as increasing redness, swelling, pain, or drainage

**The Main Advantage of Getting Medical Help**

The main advantage to getting medical help for any fishhook injury is that it can be removed under local anesthesia. This means before the hook is removed, your health care provider numbs the area with medicine.

**References:**

Haynes JH, Hines TS. Fishhook removal. In: Fowler GC, ed. Pfenninger and Fowler's Procedures for Primary Care. 4th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 190.

Otten EJ. Hunting and fishing injuries. In: Auerbach PS, Cushing TA, Harris NS, eds. Auerbach's Wilderness Medicine. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 26.

Stone DB, Scordino DJ. Foreign body removal. In: Roberts JR, Custalow CB, Thomsen TW, eds. Roberts and Hedges' Clinical Procedures in Emergency Medicine and Acute Care. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2019:chap 36.

title: Fistula | MedlinePlus
content:
**Fistula**

A fistula is an abnormal connection between two parts inside of the body.

**Causes**

Some people are born with a fistula. Other common causes of fistulas include:

* Complications from surgery
* Injury
* Infection
* Diseases, such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the cause of the fistula, where it is, and how bad it is. Some fistulas will close on their own. In some cases, you may need antibiotics and/or surgery.

**Diagnosis and Tests**

* CT Enterography (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
* Fistulogram/Sinogram (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
* Lower GI Series (Barium Enema)  (National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases)
* MR Enterography (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)

**Treatments and Therapies**

* Embolization of Brain Aneurysms and Arteriovenous Malformations/Fistulas (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
* Intracranial Vascular Treatments (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)

**Specifics**

* Anal Abscess and Fistula  (American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons)
* Anatomic Problems of the Lower GI Tract  (National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases)
* Arteriovenous Fistula (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)
* Arteriovenous Malformations (AVMs)  (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke)
* Perilymph Fistula (Vestibular Disorders Association)

**Clinical Trials**

* ClinicalTrials.gov: Fistula  (National Institutes of Health)

**Journal Articles**

* Article: Epithelialized chimeric repairing patch supports in situ healing of tracheal fistula.
* Article: Efficacy and safety of stem cell therapy for fistula management: an...

---

**Fistula**

\n\n

*   **Definition**: A fistula is an abnormal connection or passageway between two organs or between an organ and the skin.
*   **Types of Fistulas**:
    *   Esophageal atresia
    *   Tracheoesophageal fistula
    *   Gastrointestinal fistula
    *   Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
    *   Rectovaginal fistula
    *   Vaginal fistula

\n\n

**Symptoms and Diagnosis**

*   Symptoms may include:
    *   Abdominal pain
    *   Fever
    *   Weight loss
    *   Difficulty swallowing (in the case of esophageal atresia or tracheoesophageal fistula)
*   Diagnosis is typically made through imaging tests such as X-rays, CT scans, or MRI.

\n\n

**Treatment Options**

*   Treatment depends on the type and location of the fistula.
*   For some types of fistulas, such as esophageal atresia or tracheoesophageal fistula, surgical repair may be necessary.
*   In other cases, treatment may involve managing symptoms and preventing complications.

\n\n

**Patient Handouts**

*   Fistula (Medical Encyclopedia)
*   Gastrointestinal fistula (Medical Encyclopedia)

\n\n

**References and Abstracts**

*   References and abstracts from MEDLINE/PubMed (National Library of Medicine)

title: Fistula: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fistula**

A fistula is an abnormal connection between two body parts, such as an organ or blood vessel and another structure. Fistulas are usually the result of an injury or surgery. Infection or inflammation can also cause a fistula to form.

**Information**

Fistulas may occur in many parts of the body. They can form between:

* An artery and vein (arteriovenous fistula)
* Bile ducts and the surface of the skin (from gallbladder surgery)
* The cervix and vagina
* The neck and throat
* The space inside the skull and nasal sinus
* The bowel and vagina
* The colon or intestine and surface of the body, causing feces to exit through an opening other than the anus (enterocutaneous fistula)
* The stomach and surface of the skin
* The uterus and peritoneal cavity (the space between the walls of the abdomen and internal organs)
* An artery and vein in the lungs (results in blood not picking up enough oxygen in the lungs)
* The navel and gastrointestinal tract

Crohn disease can lead to fistulas between one loop of intestine and another. Injury can cause fistulas to form between arteries and veins.

**Types of Fistulas**

* Blind: open on one end only, but connects to two structures
* Complete: has openings both outside and inside the body
* Horseshoe: connects the anus to the surface of the skin after going around the rectum
* Incomplete: a tube from an internal structure that is closed on the other end and does not connect to skin

---

**Fistula**

A fistula is an abnormal connection or passageway that forms between two organs or structures in the body. It can occur in various parts of the body, including the gastrointestinal tract.

**Types of Fistulas**

There are several types of fistulas, including:

*   **Blind**: A fistula that opens on one end only, connecting to two structures.
*   **Complete**: A fistula with openings both outside and inside the body.
*   **Horseshoe**: A type of fistula that connects the anus to the surface of the skin after going around the rectum.
*   **Incomplete**: A tube from an internal structure that is closed on the other end and does not connect to the skin.

**Causes of Fistulas**

Fistulas can form due to various reasons, including:

*   **Crohn disease**: A condition that can lead to fistulas between one loop of intestine and another.
*   **Injury**: Physical trauma can cause fistulas to form between arteries and veins.

**Related Topics**

If you're interested in learning more about fistulas, you may also want to explore the following topics:

*   **Fistulas**: A related topic that provides further information on this condition.
*   **Gastrointestinal disease**: A category of diseases that affect the digestive system, including conditions that can lead to fistula formation.

**References**

The information provided in this article is based on the following sources:

*   de Prisco G, Celinski S, Spak CW. Abdominal abscesses and gastrointestinal fistulas. In: Feldman M, Friedman LS, Brandt LJ, eds. Sleisenger & Fordtran's Gastrointestinal and Liver Disease. 11th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 29.
*   Lentz GM, Fialkow M. Anal incontinence: diagnosis and management. In: Gershenson DM, Lentz GM, Valea FA, Lobo RA, eds. Comprehensive Gynecology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier;2022:chap 22.
*   Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary. 24th ed. Philadelphia, PA: F.A. Davis Company; 2021. www.tabers.com/tabersonline/view/Tabers-Dictionary/759338/all/fistula. Accessed October 19, 2023.

**Review Date**

The review date for this article is October 13, 2023.

title: Fitness Facts & Fiction Quiz: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fitness Facts & Fiction Quiz**

Which of the following is a benefit of regular exercise?

A. Better control of your weight and appetite
B. Better fitness, so its easier to do everyday activities
C. Better sleep
D. Less stress and anxiety
E. Lower risk for heart disease, diabetes, and high blood pressure
F. All of the above

The correct answer is all of the above. Getting regular exercise is one of the best things you can do for your body, mind, and spirit.

**How Much Daily Exercise Do Children Need?**

A. 15 minutes
B. 30 minutes
C. 45 minutes
D. 60 minutes

The correct answer is 60 minutes. Even children who prefer staying inside and playing video games can learn to be active during the day. They can ride their bike to school, play active computer games, or help out with chores around the house.

**Kids Are More Likely to Exercise If Their Parents Are Active Too**

A. Fact
B. Fiction

The correct answer is fact. When you are active, your child will be too. Take walks before dinner, play hoops, or throw a baseball. Encourage your child to join a sports team. Some kids prefer team sports like soccer, and others prefer sports like swimming or tennis. Let your child choose.

**Regular Exercise Is Good for Your Bones**

A. Fact
B. Fiction

The correct answer is fact. Doing weight-bearing exercises will help keep them strong and lower your risk of bone loss and breaks as you get older. Walking and strength training are good options. If you are older, haven't been active, or have a health problem, talk with your doctor before starting to exercise.

**Exercise Can Help You Fight Infections**

A. Making you more confident
B. Making your immune system stronger
C. Making you feel like nothing can hurt you

The correct answer is making your immune system stronger. Exercise helps your immune system fight off infections from bacteria and viruses. It also lowers your risk of heart disease, osteoporosis, and cancer.

**Weight or Strength Training Can Build Muscle and Improve Strength at Any Age**

A. Fact
B. Fiction

The correct answer is fact. Doing weight or strength training will build your muscles and make you stronger. Even older adults can gain strength from these exercises. Use free-weights, resistance bands, or weight machines at a gym. Start slow, and work up to two 30-minute sessions every week.

**This Is an Important Part of an Exercise Program**

A. Warming up and cooling down
B. Choosing the right gym
C. Push-ups and sit-ups
D. Stretching
E. A and D

The correct answer is A and D, warming up and cooling down and stretching. Warm up your muscles and joints with gentle, full-body movements for 5 to 10 minutes before exercising.

---

**Fitness Facts & Fiction Quiz**

\n\n

**Warm Up and Cool Down**

This can help prevent injury. Cool down by walking slowly then stretching muscles to help prevent muscle strains after exercise.

\n\n

**Exercises for Balance**

Some exercises can make you less likely to fall.

* Fact: Exercises that improve balance make you stronger, more flexible, and increase how long you can be active.
	+ One simple example is to stand on one foot while waiting in line. Or sit down and stand up without using your hands. Tai Chi and yoga can also help you develop balance.

\n\n

**Preventing Sports Injuries**

Which of the following can help prevent sports injuries?

* All of the above: Wearing safety gear, cross-training, slowly increasing how long and how hard you exercise, warming up and cooling down.
	+ But if you do get hurt, stop playing. Never try to work through the pain because this can cause more damage. Minor aches and pains you can treat yourself at home. More serious injuries should be treated by a doctor right away.

\n\n

**Finding Time for Exercise**

Some people just dont have time to be physically active.

* Fiction: Being more active takes effort, but it doesnt have to take a lot of time.
	+ Break 30 minutes into three 10-minute sessions and work it into your schedule. Plan to exercise during the time of day you like best, before work, at lunch, or in the evening. Or, build it into your commute. Find what works best for you.

\n\n

B. Fiction

D. Stretching
E. A and D

The correct answer is A and D, warming up and cooling down and stretching.

---

**Fitness Facts & Fiction Quiz**

**Part 2/2**

\n\n

**Warm Up and Cool Down**

Warming up your muscles and joints with gentle, full-body movements for 5 to 10 minutes before exercising can help prevent injury. Cooling down by walking slowly then stretching muscles after exercise can also help prevent muscle strains.

\n\n

**Exercises That Help You Not Fall**

Exercises that improve balance make you stronger, more flexible, and increase how long you can be active. One simple example is to stand on one foot while waiting in line or sit down and stand up without using your hands. Tai Chi and yoga can also help you develop balance.

\n\n

Wearing safety gear, cross-training, slowly increasing how long and how hard you exercise, and warming up and cooling down can all help prevent sports injuries. If you do get hurt, stop playing and never try to work through the pain, as this can cause more damage.

\n\n

**You Don't Have Time?**

Being more active takes effort, but it doesn't have to take a lot of time. Break 30 minutes into three 10-minute sessions and work it into your schedule. Plan to exercise during the time of day you like best, before work, at lunch, or in the evening. Or, build it into your commute.

\n\n

**Benefits of Exercise**

Exercise can help prevent sports injuries, improve balance, and increase physical activity without taking up too much time. It's also essential for overall health and well-being.

title: Flank pain: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Flank Pain**

**What is flank pain?**

Flank pain is pain in one side of the body between the upper belly area (abdomen) and the back.

**Considerations**

Flank pain can be a sign of a kidney problem. But, since many organs are in this area, other causes are possible. If you have flank pain and fever, chills, blood in the urine, or frequent or urgent urination, then a kidney problem is the likely cause. It could be a sign ofkidney stones.

**Causes**

Flank pain may be caused by any of the following:

* Arthritis or infection of the spine
* Back problem, such as disk disease
* Gallbladder disease
* Gastrointestinal disease
* Liver disease
* Muscle spasm
* Kidney stone, infection, or abscess
* Shingles (pain with one-sided rash)
* Spinal fracture

**Home Care**

Treatment depends on the cause.

* Rest, physical therapy, and exercise may be recommended if the pain is caused by muscle spasm. You will be taught how to do these exercises at home.
* Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and physical therapy may be prescribed for flank pain caused by spinal arthritis.
* Antibiotics are used to treat most kidney infections. You will also receive fluids and pain medicine. You may need to stay in the hospital.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your health care provider if you have any of the following:

* Flank pain along with a high fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting
* Blood (red or brown color) in the urine
* Unexplained flank pain that continues

**What to Expect at Your Office Visit**

The provider will examine you. You will be asked about your medical history and symptoms, including:

* Location of the pain
* When the pain began, if it's always there or comes and goes, if it's getting worse
* If your pain is related to activities or bending over
* What the pain feels like, such as dull and aching or sharp
* What other symptoms you have

The following tests may be done:

* Abdominal CT scan
* Blood tests to check kidney and liver function
* Ultrasound to look at your internal organs
* Chest or abdominal x-ray
* Kidney or abdominal ultrasound
* Lumbosacral spine x-ray
* Tests to check the kidneys and bladder, such as urinalysis and urine culture, or cystourethrogram

---

**Flank Pain**

Are you experiencing pain in your side? It could be a sign of a serious underlying condition. In this article, we'll explore the causes and treatment options for flank pain.

**Causes**

Flank pain may be caused by any of the following:

*   **Arthritis or infection of the spine**: Inflammation or infection in the spinal column can cause pain in the side.
*   **Back problem, such as disk disease**: A herniated or ruptured disk can put pressure on nearby nerves, causing pain in the flank.
*   **Gallbladder disease**: Gallstones or inflammation of the gallbladder can cause pain in the upper right quadrant of the abdomen, which may radiate to the side.
*   **Gastrointestinal disease**: Conditions such as Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, or irritable bowel syndrome can cause abdominal pain that may radiate to the flank.
*   **Liver disease**: Liver conditions like hepatitis or cirrhosis can cause pain in the upper right quadrant of the abdomen, which may spread to the side.
*   **Muscle spasm**: Tightness in the muscles of the back or abdomen can cause pain in the flank.
*   **Kidney stone, infection, or abscess**: A kidney stone, infection, or abscess can cause severe pain in the flank that may radiate to the lower back.
*   **Shingles (pain with one-sided rash)**: Shingles can cause a painful rash on one side of the body, which may be accompanied by pain in the flank.
*   **Spinal fracture**: A spinal fracture can cause sudden, severe pain in the flank that may radiate to the lower back.

**Home Care**

Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the flank pain. Here are some possible treatment options:

*   **Rest, physical therapy, and exercise**: If the pain is caused by muscle spasm, rest, physical therapy, and exercise may be recommended.
*   **Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and physical therapy**: For spinal arthritis, NSAIDs and physical therapy may be prescribed to reduce pain and inflammation.
*   **Antibiotics**: Most kidney infections are treated with antibiotics, which may be administered orally or intravenously.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your healthcare provider if you experience any of the following:

*   **Flank pain along with a high fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting**: If you have flank pain accompanied by a fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting, seek medical attention immediately.
*   **Blood (red or brown color) in the urine**: If you notice blood in your urine, contact your healthcare provider promptly.
*   **Unexplained flank pain that continues**: If you experience persistent flank pain without an apparent cause, consult your healthcare provider.

**What to Expect at Your Office Visit**

During your office visit, your healthcare provider will:

*   **Examine you**: A thorough physical examination will be performed to assess the location and severity of the pain.
*   **Ask about your medical history and symptoms**: You'll be asked about your medical history, including any previous conditions or surgeries, as well as your symptoms, such as the location, duration, and characteristics of the pain.
*   **Perform diagnostic tests**: Depending on the suspected underlying cause, various diagnostic tests may be ordered, such as abdominal CT scans, blood tests to check kidney and liver function, ultrasounds, chest or abdominal x-rays, lumbosacral spine x-rays, or urinalysis and urine culture.

**Alternative Names**

Flank pain is also known as:

*   **Pain - side**
*   **Side pain**

By understanding the causes and treatment options for flank pain, you can take steps to prevent and manage this condition. If you experience persistent or severe flank pain, consult your healthcare provider promptly.

---

**Flank Pain**

\n\n

*   **Causes of flank pain in adults**
    *   Nephrolithiasis (kidney stones)
    *   Pyelonephritis (infection of the kidney)
    *   Ureteral obstruction
    *   Rupture of a kidney or ureter
    *   Pancreatitis
    *   Gastrointestinal disease

\n\n

*   **Diagnosis**
    *   Imaging tests such as X-rays, CT scans, and ultrasound
    *   Laboratory tests such as blood and urine analysis
    *   Physical examination

\n\n

*   **Treatment**
    *   Nephrolithiasis: treatment of underlying cause, pain management
    *   Pyelonephritis: antibiotics
    *   Ureteral obstruction: relief of obstruction
    *   Rupture of a kidney or ureter: surgical repair
    *   Pancreatitis: treatment of underlying cause, supportive care
    *   Gastrointestinal disease: treatment of underlying cause, supportive care

\n\n

*   **Prevention**
    *   Nephrolithiasis: adequate hydration, diet modification
    *   Pyelonephritis: good hygiene, vaccination against certain infections
    *   Ureteral obstruction: regular check-ups for people with risk factors
    *   Rupture of a kidney or ureter: prompt medical attention if symptoms occur
    *   Pancreatitis: healthy lifestyle, early treatment of underlying conditions
    *   Gastrointestinal disease: healthy lifestyle, early treatment of underlying conditions

title: Flat bones: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Flat Bones**

\n\n

*   **Definition**: Flat bones are made up of a layer of spongy bone between two thin layers of compact bone.
*   **Shape**: They have a flat shape, not rounded.
*   **Examples**: Examples include the skull and rib bones.
*   **Marrow**: Flat bones have marrow, but they do not have a bone marrow cavity.

title: Flat feet: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Flat Feet**

\n\n

**What are Flat Feet?**

Flat feet refer to a change in foot shape where the foot does not have a normal arch when standing.

\n\n

**Causes of Flat Feet**

*   **Normal in Infants and Toddlers**: The condition is normal in infants and toddlers.
*   **Loose Tendons**: Flat feet occur because the tissues holding the joints in the foot together (called tendons) are loose.
*   **Hereditary Conditions**: Some hereditary conditions cause loose tendons and ligaments, such as Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome and Marfan Syndrome.
*   **Aging, Injuries, or Illness**: Aging, injuries, or illness may harm the tendons and cause flat feet to develop in a person who has already formed arches.

\n\n

**Symptoms of Flat Feet**

*   **Most Cases Are Painless**: Most flat feet do not cause pain or other problems.
*   **Children's Symptoms**: Children don't often have foot pain, ankle pain, or lower leg pain. They should be evaluated by a health care provider if this occurs.
*   **Adults' Symptoms**: Symptoms in adults may include tired or achy feet after long periods of standing or playing sports.

\n\n

**Exams and Tests for Flat Feet**

*   **Provider's Examination**: In people with flat feet, the instep of the foot comes in contact with the ground when standing.
*   **Toe-Standing Test**: To diagnose the problem, the provider will ask you to stand on your toes. If an arch forms, the flat foot is called flexible.

\n\n

**Treatment for Flat Feet**

*   **No Treatment Needed**: Flat feet in a child do not need treatment if they are not causing pain or walking problems.
*   **Flexible Flat Feet**: In older children and adults, flexible flat feet that do not cause pain or walking problems do not need further treatment.

\n\n

**Possible Complications After Surgery**

*   **Failure of the Fused Bones to Heal**
*   **Foot Deformity That Does Not Go Away**
*   **Infection**
*   **Loss of Ankle Movement**
*   **Pain That Does Not Go Away**
*   **Problems with Shoe Fit**

---

**Flat Feet**

Flat feet refer to a change in foot shape where the foot does not have a normal arch when standing.

**Causes**

*   The condition is normal in infants and toddlers.
*   Flat feet occur because the tissues holding the joints in the foot together (called tendons) are loose.
*   The tissues tighten and form an arch as children grow older. This will take place by the time the child is 2 or 3 years old.
*   Most people have normal arches by the time they are adults. However, the arch may never form in some people.
*   Some hereditary conditions cause loose tendons and ligaments.
    *   Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
    *   Marfan Syndrome

People born with these conditions may have flat feet.

Aging, injuries, or illness may harm the tendons and cause flat feet to develop in a person who has already formed arches. This type of flat foot may occur only on one side.

Rarely, painful flat feet in children may be caused by a condition in which two or more of the bones in the foot grow or fuse together. This condition is called tarsal coalition.

**Symptoms**

*   Most flat feet do not cause pain or other problems.
*   Children don't often have foot pain, ankle pain, or lower leg pain. They should be evaluated by a health care provider if this occurs.
*   Symptoms in adults may include tired or achy feet after long periods of standing or playing sports. You also may have pain on the outside of the ankle.

For patients that have had flat foot for a long time, you may develop changes in the appearance and flexibility of your toes also. You can have pain in the deformed toes.

**Exams and Tests**

*   In people with flat feet, the instep of the foot comes in contact with the ground when standing.
*   To diagnose the problem, the provider will ask you to stand on your toes. If an arch forms, the flat foot is called flexible. You will not need any more tests or treatment.

If the arch does not form with toe-standing (called rigid flat feet), or if there is pain, other tests may be needed, including:

*   X-rays
*   MRI
*   CT scans

**Treatment**

*   In older children and adults, flexible flat feet that do not cause pain or walking problems do not need further treatment.
*   If you have pain due to flexible flat feet, the following may help:
    *   An arch-support (orthotic) that you put in your shoe. You can buy this at the store or have it custom-made.
    *   Special shoes.
    *   Calf muscle stretches.

Rigid or painful flat feet need to be checked by a provider. The treatment depends on the cause of the flat feet.

For tarsal coalition, treatment starts with rest and possibly a cast. Surgery may be needed if pain does not improve.

In more severe cases, surgery may be needed to:

*   Clean or repair the tendon
*   Transfer a tendon to restore the arch
*   Fuse joints in the foot into a corrected position

Flat feet in older adults can be treated with pain relievers, orthotics, and sometimes surgery.

---

**Flat Feet**

**What is a flat foot?**

A flat foot is a condition where the arch of the foot does not form properly.

**Types of Flat Feet**

There are two types of flat feet:

*   **Flexible flat feet**: This type of flat foot can be treated with exercises, orthotics, and sometimes surgery.
*   **Rigid flat feet**: This type of flat foot is more serious and may require surgery to correct the deformity.

**Causes of Flat Feet**

Flat feet can be caused by:

*   **Genetics**: Some people are born with flat feet due to their genetic makeup.
*   **Injury**: A severe injury to the foot or ankle can cause flat feet.
*   **Tarsal coalition**: This is a condition where two bones in the foot fuse together, causing flat feet.

**Symptoms of Flat Feet**

The symptoms of flat feet include:

*   **Pain**: People with flat feet may experience pain in their feet, ankles, or lower legs.
*   **Difficulty walking**: Flat feet can make it difficult to walk or run without experiencing pain or discomfort.

**Diagnosing Flat Feet**

To diagnose flat feet, a healthcare provider will typically perform the following tests:

*   **Physical examination**: The provider will examine the foot and ankle to look for signs of flat feet.
*   **X-ray**: An X-ray may be taken to rule out other conditions that may be causing the symptoms.

**Treatment Options**

The treatment options for flat feet depend on the type and severity of the condition. Some common treatment options include:

*   **Exercises**: Exercises can help strengthen the muscles in the foot and ankle, which can help alleviate pain and discomfort.
*   **Orthotics**: Orthotics are custom-made shoe inserts that can help redistribute pressure on the foot and alleviate pain.
*   **Surgery**: In some cases, surgery may be necessary to correct the deformity or relieve pain.

**Prevention**

While most cases of flat feet are not preventable, wearing well-supported shoes can help reduce the risk of developing the condition.

---

**Flat Feet**

\n\n

**Correction of Flatfoot Deformity in the Adult**

In adults, flat feet can be corrected through surgical procedures. According to Myerson MS and Kadakia AR, correction of flatfoot deformity in the adult involves various techniques aimed at restoring the normal anatomy of the foot. This approach is crucial for individuals experiencing pain or discomfort due to the condition.

\n\n

**The Foot and Toes**

Understanding the structure and function of the foot is essential in addressing flat feet. Winell JJ and Davidson RS discuss the importance of recognizing the anatomical differences between the human foot and those of other primates. This knowledge helps in identifying the root causes of foot-related issues, including flat feet.

\n\n

**Disorders of Tendons and Fascia**

Grear BJ provides valuable insights into disorders affecting tendons and fascia in individuals with pes planus. By examining the relationship between these conditions and flat feet, healthcare professionals can develop effective treatment plans to alleviate symptoms and prevent further complications.

\n\n

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics**

*   Foot Injuries and Disorders

title: Flavoxate: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Flavoxate: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**What is Flavoxate?**

*   Pronounced as (fla vox' ate)
*   A medication used to treat overactive bladder and relieve painful, frequent, or nighttime urination and urgency that may occur with infections of the prostate, bladder, or kidneys.

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Flavoxate is used to treat overactive bladder (a condition in which the bladder muscles contract uncontrollably and cause frequent urination, urgent need to urinate, and inability to control urination) relieve painful, frequent, or nighttime urination and urgency that may occur with infections of the prostate, bladder, or kidneys.

**How should this medicine be used?**

*   Flavoxate comes as a tablet.
*   It usually is taken three or four times a day.
*   This drug may be taken with or without food.
*   Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand.
*   Take flavoxate exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before taking flavoxate,

*   tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take.
*   tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma, ulcers, paralytic ileus, or obstructive disease (blockage) of the stomach, kidneys, or intestines.
*   tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to flavoxate or any other drugs.
*   tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. If you become pregnant while taking flavoxate, call your doctor.
*   if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking flavoxate.

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

Take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. However, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Flavoxate may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away:

*   vomiting
*   upset stomach
*   dry mouth or throat
*   blurred vision
*   eye pain
*   increased sensitivity of your eyes to light

If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately:

*   confusion (especially in the elderly)
*   skin rash
*   fast or irregular heartbeat
*   severe dizziness or drowsiness
*   sore throat with fever

---

**Flavoxate: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 2/2)**

**Side Effects**

If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately:

* confusion (especially in the elderly)
* skin rash
* fast or irregular heartbeat
* severe dizziness or drowsiness
* sore throat with fever

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online or by phone.

**Storage and Disposal**

Keep this medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community.

**In Case of Emergency/Overdose**

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**Other Information**

Keep all appointments with your doctor.

Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies.

**Brand Names**

Urispas

This branded product is no longer on the market. Generic alternatives may be available.

title: Fleas: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Fleas**

_Fleas are small insects that feed on the blood of humans, dogs, cats, and other warm-blooded animals._

**Causes**

*   Fleas prefer to live on dogs and cats.
*   They may also be found on humans and other warm-blooded animals.
*   Pet owners may not be affected by fleas until their pet has been gone for a period of time. Fleas look for other sources of food and begin to bite humans.

**Symptoms**

*   Bites often occur on the legs and places where clothes fit close to the body, such as the waist, buttocks, thighs, and lower abdomen.
*   Symptoms of flea bites include:
    *   Small red bumps, often three bumps together, that are very itchy
    *   Blisters if the person has an allergy to flea bites

**Exams and Tests**

*   Usually, a diagnosis can be made when your health care provider examines the skin where the bites are.
*   Questions may be asked about contact with animals such as cats and dogs.
*   In rare cases, a skin biopsy is done to check for other skin problems.

**Treatment**

*   You can use an over-the-counter 1% hydrocortisone cream to relieve itching.
*   Antihistamines you can take by mouth may also help with itching.

**Possible Complications**

*   Scratching can lead to a skin infection.
*   Fleas can carry bacteria that cause diseases in humans, such as typhus and plague. The bacteria can be transmitted to humans by flea bites.

**Prevention**

*   Prevention may not always be possible. The goal is to get rid of the fleas.
*   This can be done by treating your home, pets, and outside areas with chemicals (pesticides).
*   Small children should not be in the home when pesticides are being used.
*   Birds and fish must be protected when chemicals are sprayed.
*   Home foggers and flea collars do not always work to get rid of fleas. Always consult your veterinarian for help.

**Alternative Names**

*   Pulicosis; Dog fleas; Siphonaptera

---

In rare cases, a skin biopsy is done to check for other skin problems.

**Possible Complications**

Fleas can carry bacteria that cause diseases in humans, such as typhus and plague. The bacteria can be transmitted to humans by flea bites.

**Prevention**

Prevention may not always be possible. The goal is to get rid of the fleas. This can be done by treating your home, pets, and outside areas with chemicals (pesticides). Small children should not be in the home when pesticides are being used. Birds and fish must be protected when chemicals are sprayed. Home foggers and flea collars do not always work to get rid of fleas. Always consult your veterinarian for help.

**References**
