title: Flecainide: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Flecainide**

*pronounced as (flek' a nide)*

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Flecainide is used to prevent certain types of life-threatening irregular heartbeats. Flecainide is in a class of medications called antiarrhythmics. It works by slowing electrical signals in the heart to stabilize the heart rhythm.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Flecainide comes as a tablet to take by mouth. It is usually taken once every 12 hours. Some people may take flecainide once every 8 hours if they experience side effects or if their condition cannot be controlled by taking flecainide every 12 hours. Take flecainide at around the same times every day. Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. Take flecainide exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

You may be hospitalized when you begin your treatment with flecainide. Your doctor will monitor you carefully during this time and for as long as you continue to take flecainide. Your doctor will probably start you on a low dose of flecainide and gradually increase your dose, not more than once every 4 days. Your doctor may also decrease your dose once your condition is controlled.

Flecainide may control your condition, but will not cure it. Continue to take flecainide even if you feel well. Do not stop taking flecainide without talking to your doctor. If you suddenly stop taking flecainide, your condition may become worse.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Tell your doctor if you have atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter (conditions in which the upper chambers of the heart do not beat effectively). People with atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter who take flecainide may have a higher risk of developing certain types of irregular heartbeats.

Talk to your doctor about the risks of taking flecainide.

---

**Flecainide: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 2/3)**

*This medication is used to treat abnormal heart rhythms.*

**Other uses for this medicine**

This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before taking flecainide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to flecainide or any other medications. Also, inform them about all the prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while taking flecainide.

The following nonprescription product may interact with flecainide: cimetidine (Tagamet). Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking this medication before you start taking flecainide. Do not start this medication while taking flecainide without discussing with your healthcare provider.

Tell your doctor if you have heart block, a pacemaker, or any type of heart disease; low or high levels of potassium in the blood; liver or kidney disease; or follow a strict vegetarian diet.

Also, inform your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. If you become pregnant while taking flecainide, call your doctor.

If you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking flecainide.

If you are giving this medication to an infant, be sure to talk to the doctor if there will be any major changes in the amount of milk the infant drinks. Milk can affect how the medication is absorbed in the body.

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet.

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

Take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. However, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Flecainide may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away:

* dizziness
* changes in vision
* headache
* weakness
* uncontrollable shaking of a part of your body
* constipation
* stomach pain

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately:

* fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat
* chest pain
* shortness of breath
* extreme tiredness
* nausea
* loss of appetite
* persistent cough with blood-tinged mucus
* swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs
* confusion
* unusual bleeding or bruising
* pain in the upper right part of the stomach
* yellowing of the skin or eyes
* flu-like symptoms

Flecainide may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online or by phone.

---

**Flecainide: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

*er right part of the stomach*
yellowing of the skin or eyes*
flu-like symptoms*

Flecainide may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online or by phone.

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Keep this medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community. Visit the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website for more information.

Keep all medication out of sight and reach of children as many containers are not child-resistant. Always lock safety caps. Place the medication in a safe location  one that is up and away and out of their sight and reach.

**In case of emergency/overdose**

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at . If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

Symptoms of overdose may include:
nausea
vomiting
seizures
slow, fast, or irregular heartbeat
loss of consciousness
sudden death

**What other information should I know?**

Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. Your doctor will order certain lab tests to check your body's response to flecainide.

Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies.

**Brand names**

Tambocor

title: Flibanserin: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Flibanserin: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

\n\n

**What is Flibanserin?**

Flibanserin is a medication used to treat low libido in women. It is also known as Addyi.

\n\n

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Flibanserin is prescribed to women who have low libido and are experiencing distress due to their lack of interest in sex.

\n\n

**How should this medicine be used?**

Flibanserin should be taken once a day at bedtime. It is essential to follow the dosage instructions provided by your doctor or pharmacist.

\n\n

**Other uses for this medicine**

Flibanserin is specifically designed to treat low libido in women. It is not intended for use in men or for any other purpose.

\n\n

**What special precautions should I follow?**

If you have liver disease or a history of heavy drinking, inform your doctor before taking flibanserin. Drinking alcohol while taking this medication can increase the risk of very low blood pressure.

\n\n

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

Avoid eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking flibanserin, as it may interact with other medications.

\n\n

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. However, if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular dosing schedule.

\n\n

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Common side effects of flibanserin include dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately and lie down.

\n\n

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Store flibanserin at room temperature, away from moisture and heat. Dispose of unused or expired medication properly.

\n\n

**In case of emergency/overdose**

If you experience severe dizziness, fainting, or lightheadedness after taking flibanserin, seek medical attention immediately.

\n\n

**What other information should I know?**

Your doctor will provide you with the manufacturer's patient information sheet (Medication Guide) when you begin treatment with flibanserin. Read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. You can also visit the FDA website to obtain the Medication Guide.

\n\n

**Brand names**

Flibanserin is available under the brand name Addyi.

---

**Flibanserin: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 2/3)**

**Why is this medication prescribed?**

Flibanserin is used to treat women with hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD; a low sexual desire that causes distress or interpersonal difficulty) who have not experienced menopause (change of life; the end of monthly menstrual periods). Flibanserin should not be used for the treatment of HSDD in women who have gone through menopause or in men or to improve sexual performance. Flibanserin is in a class of medications called a serotonin receptor 1A agonist/serotonin receptor 2A antagonist. It works by changing the activity of serotonin and other natural substances in the brain.

**How should this medicine be used?**

Flibanserin comes as a tablet to take by mouth. It is usually taken once daily at bedtime. Take flibanserin at bedtime every day. Follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. Take flibanserin exactly as directed. Do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor.

If your symptoms do not improve after 8 weeks of treatment, call your doctor.

**Other uses for this medicine**

This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

Before taking flibanserin,

* tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to flibanserin, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in flibanserin tablets. Ask your pharmacist or check the Medication Guide for a list of the ingredients.
* tell your doctor and pharmacist what other prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while taking flibanserin. Your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects.
* the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with flibanserin: gingko; resveratrol; St. John's wort; cimetidine (Tagamet); heartburn medications such as proton pump inhibitors including dexlansoprazole (Dexilant), esomeprazole (Nexium, Vimovo), lansoprazole (Prevacid), omeprazole (Prilosec), or rabeprazole (Aciphex); ranitidine (Zantac). Be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking these medications before you start taking flibanserin. Do not start any of these medications while taking flibanserin without discussing with your healthcare provider.
* tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. If you become pregnant while taking flibanserin, call your doctor. Do not breastfeed while taking flibanserin.
* you should know that flibanserin may make you drowsy. Do not drive a car or operate machinery until at least 6 hours after your dose of flibanserin and until you know how this medication affects you.

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**

Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet.

**What should I do if I forget a dose?**

Take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. If it is close to bedtime, take the dose at bedtime. Do not double the dose unless directed by your doctor.

---

**Flibanserin: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

\n\n

**What should I do?**

Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet.

\n\n

**What if I forget a dose?**

If a dose is missed at bedtime, take the next dose at bedtime the following day. Do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one.

\n\n

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

Flibanserin may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away:

* nausea
* tiredness
* difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep
* dry mouth
* constipation

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the IMPORTANT WARNING and SPECIAL PRECAUTIONS sections, call your doctor immediately:

* excessive sleepiness
* hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing
* hives; itching
* swelling of the face, lips, or mouth

Flibanserin may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online (https://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch) or by phone (1-800-332-1088).

\n\n

**What should I know about storage and disposal of this medication?**

Keep this medication in the container it came in, tightly closed, and out of reach of children. Store it at room temperature and away from excess heat and moisture (not in the bathroom).

Keep all medication out of sight and reach of children as many containers are not child-resistant. Always lock safety caps. Place the medication in a safe location  one that is up and away and out of their sight and reach. https://www.upandaway.org

Dispose of unneeded medications in a way so that pets, children, and other people cannot take them. Do not flush this medication down the toilet. Use a medicine take-back program. Talk to your pharmacist about take-back programs in your community. Visit the FDA's Safe Disposal of Medicines website https://goo.gl/c4Rm4p for more information.

\n\n

**In case of emergency/overdose**

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

\n\n

**What other information should I know?**

Do not let anyone else take your medication. Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies.

\n\n

**Brand names**

Addyi

title: Floods - Multiple Languages: MedlinePlus
content:
**Floods**

Floods can be a serious threat to public health, causing injuries and fatalities due to drowning, electrocution, and other hazards. In addition to these immediate risks, floods can also lead to the spread of waterborne diseases, such as cholera and dysentery.

**Prevention and Preparation**

To minimize the risks associated with floods, it is essential to take preventive measures and prepare for potential flooding events. This includes:

*   **Creating a flood emergency plan**: Develop a plan that outlines evacuation routes, emergency contact numbers, and a meeting point in case of separation.
*   **Staying informed**: Monitor local weather forecasts, sign up for emergency alerts, and stay tuned to local news for updates on flood conditions.
*   **Protecting property**: Consider installing flood-proof doors, sealing walls with waterproof materials, and elevating electrical outlets and switches above potential flood levels.
*   **Stocking an emergency kit**: Assemble a kit containing essential items such as food, water, first aid supplies, and a battery-powered radio.

**During a Flood**

If you find yourself in the midst of a flood:

*   **Evacuate immediately**: If instructed to do so by local authorities or if your life is at risk due to rising waters.
*   **Avoid walking through floodwaters**: These can contain hidden dangers such as sharp objects, contaminated water, and electrocution hazards.
*   **Conserve energy and stay safe**: Avoid strenuous activities, stay indoors, and keep a battery-powered radio handy for updates.

**After a Flood**

Once the waters have receded:

*   **Be cautious when returning home**: Watch out for fallen power lines, structural damage, and potential health hazards like mold and bacteria growth.
*   **Seek medical attention if necessary**: If you've been exposed to floodwaters or experienced injuries during the event.

By being prepared, staying informed, and taking necessary precautions, you can reduce the risks associated with floods and protect yourself and your loved ones from harm.

title: Floods: MedlinePlus
content:
**Floods**

**Summary**

Floods are common in the United States. Weather such as heavy rain, thunderstorms, hurricanes, or tsunamis can cause flooding. Flooding can also happen when a river or stream overflows its bank, when a levee is breached, or when a dam breaks. Flash floods, which can develop quickly, often have a dangerous wall of roaring water.

**Be Aware of Flood Hazards**

*   Be aware of flood hazards no matter where you live, but especially if you live in a low-lying area, near water or downstream from a dam.
*   Although there are no guarantees of safety during a flood, you can take actions to protect yourself. You should have a disaster plan. Being prepared can help reduce fear, anxiety, and losses.

**Protect Yourself**

*   Take actions to protect yourself during a flood.
*   Have a disaster plan in place.
*   Being prepared can help reduce fear, anxiety, and losses.

**Federal Emergency Management Agency**

Learn more about floods from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).

title: Floxuridine: MedlinePlus Drug Information
content:
**Floxuridine: MedlinePlus Drug Information**

**Category:** drug&supplements

**Why is this medication prescribed?**
Floxuridine is used to treat cancer of gastrointestinal (GI) tract (cancer of the stomach or intestines) that has spread to the liver. Floxuridine is in a class of medications called antimetabolites. It works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells in your body.

**How should this medicine be used?**
Floxuridine comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid to be continuously injected intra-arterially (into an artery) that supplies blood to the tumor.

**Other uses for this medicine**
This medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

**What special precautions should I follow?**

*   Before receiving floxuridine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to floxuridine, fluorouracil, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in floxuridine injection. Ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.
*   Tell your doctor and pharmacist what other prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while receiving floxuridine injection. Your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects.
*   Tell your doctor if you have an infection or are not able to eat enough or a good balance of food. Your doctor may not want you to receive floxuridine injection.
*   Tell your doctor if you have previously received radiation (x-ray) therapy or treatment with other chemotherapy medications or if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease.
*   Tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. You should not become pregnant or breast-feed while you are receiving floxuridine injection. If you become pregnant while receiving floxuridine injection, call your doctor. Floxuridine may harm the fetus.

**What special dietary instructions should I follow?**
Unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet.

**What side effects can this medication cause?**

*   Nausea
*   Vomiting
*   Loss of appetite or weight
*   Diarrhea
*   Abdominal pain
*   Dry, red, and itchy skin
*   Hair loss
*   Pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, bleeding, or sores in the place where the medication was injected

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

*   Sore throat
*   Ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection
*   Unusual bleeding or bruising
*   Bloody or black, tarry stools
*   Bloody vomit; or vomiting blood or brown material that resembles coffee grounds
*   Pink, red, or dark brown urine
*   Chest pain
*   Hives
*   Difficulty breathing or swallowing

---

**Floxuridine: MedlinePlus Drug Information (Part 2/2)**

\n\n**What side effects can this medication cause?**

*   nausea
*   vomiting
*   loss of appetite or weight
*   diarrhea
*   abdominal pain
*   dry, red, and itchy skin
*   hair loss
*   pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, bleeding, or sores in the place where the medication was injected

Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment:

*   sores in the mouth and throat
*   extreme tiredness or weakness
*   fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection
*   unusual bleeding or bruising
*   bloody or black, tarry stools
*   bloody vomit; or vomiting blood or brown material that resembles coffee grounds
*   pink, red, or dark brown urine
*   chest pain
*   hives
*   difficulty breathing or swallowing

**In case of emergency/overdose**

If you experience a serious side effect, you or your doctor may send a report to the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program online (https://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch) or by phone (1-800-332-1088).

In case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. Information is also available online at https://www.poisonhelp.org/help. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

Symptoms of overdose may include:

*   nausea
*   vomiting
*   diarrhea
*   fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection
*   unusual bleeding or bruising
*   bloody or black, tarry stools
*   bloody vomit; or vomiting blood or brown material that resembles coffee grounds
*   pink, red, or dark brown urine

**What other information should I know?**

Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. Your doctor will order certain tests to check your body's response to floxuridine.

Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies.

title: Flu (Influenza) Test: MedlinePlus Medical Test
content:
**Flu (Influenza) Test**

**What is a flu (influenza) test?**

The flu, also known as influenza, is a respiratory infection caused by viruses. Most flu tests check a sample of fluid from your nose or throat to find out if you're infected with a flu virus.

**Understanding the Flu**

The flu usually spreads from person to person through coughingor sneezing. You can also get the flu by touching a surface that has the virus on it, and then touching your nose, eyes, or mouth. The flu can be serious, or even deadly, especially for children under age 5, adults age 65 and over, and people with certain chronic (long-term) illnesses.

**Types of Flu Tests**

There are two main types of tests for seasonal flu:

*   **Rapid Influenza Antigen Tests**: These tests check your fluid sample for certain proteins (antigens) found on flu viruses. They can provide results in less than 30 minutes, but aren't as accurate as other types of flu tests.
*   **Molecular Flu Tests**: These tests are more accurate than rapid antigen tests. They check your sample for genetic material from flu viruses.

**Why Do I Need a Flu Test?**

If you have flu symptoms, testing can help you decide what to do next, such as starting antiviral medicine, and taking steps to lower your chances of spreading the virus to others.

**Symptoms of the Flu**

Symptoms of the flu may include:

*   Fever
*   Chills
*   Muscle or body aches
*   Fatigue
*   Headache
*   Runny or stuffy nose
*   Sore throat
*   Cough

**Who Needs a Flu Test?**

Your provider may be more likely to order a flu test if you have symptoms and a high risk of developing a serious illness from the flu and other respiratory infections. Testing helps your provider make sure you get the right treatment to lower your risk.

**What Happens During a Flu Test?**

If you are tested at your provider's office or other health care setting, a fluid sample may be collected using:

*   A swab test
*   A nasal aspirate or wash

---

**Flu (Influenza) Test**

\n\n

**What is a Flu (Influenza) Test?**

Flu is short for influenza. It is a respiratory infection caused by viruses. Respiratory infections may affect your nose, throat, and/or lungs. Most flu tests check a sample of fluid from your nose or throat to find out if you're infected with a flu virus.

\n\n

**Types of Flu Tests**

There are two main types of tests for seasonal flu:

*   **Rapid Influenza Antigen Tests**: These tests check your fluid sample for certain proteins (antigens) found on flu viruses. They can provide results in less than 30 minutes, and you can do them at home.
*   **Molecular Flu Tests**: These tests are more accurate than rapid antigen tests. They check your sample for genetic material from flu viruses.

\n\n

**Preparing for a Flu Test**

You don't need any special preparations for a flu test.

\n\n

**Risks Associated with a Flu Test**

If your throat or nose is swabbed, you may feel a gagging sensation or even a tickle. A nasal aspirate or wash may feel uncomfortable. These effects are temporary.

\n\n

**Interpreting Flu Test Results**

The results of your flu test tell you if signs of influenza A or B virus were found in your sample. Your results are usually described as "positive" or "negative."

*   **Positive Result**: This means you most likely have the seasonal flu. It's essential to limit your contact with others to prevent infecting them.
*   **Negative Result**: This means you may not have the flu, but it's possible that your test was a false negative (when your test says you don't have the flu, but you really do).

\n\n

**What to Do After a Flu Test**

If you have positive test results and flu-like symptoms:

*   Get plenty of rest
*   Drink lots of liquids
*   Take over-the-counter pain relievers, such as acetaminophen and ibuprofen, to help with fever and aches (but not aspirin for children and teens)
*   Follow your provider's advice on antiviral medicine

If you have negative test results and flu-like symptoms:

*   Ask your provider what you should do next
*   Consider more testing, especially if your first test was a rapid antigen flu test

---

**Flu (Influenza) Test: MedlinePlus Medical Test**

**What is it used for?**

If you have symptoms of a respiratory infection, a test for common seasonal flu may be used to help find out if the influenza A or B virus is causing your illness. Knowing whether you have the flu is especially important if you have a high risk of becoming seriously ill from the flu. The test results can help your provider decide if medicine could help treat your illness and which one might help you.

**Why do I need a flu test?**

If you have flu symptoms, testing can help you decide what to do next, such as starting antiviral medicine, and taking steps to lower your chances of spreading the virus to others.

**Symptoms of the Flu**

* Fever
* Chills
* Muscle or body aches
* Fatigue
* Headache
* Runny or stuffy nose
* Sore throat
* Cough

**Who Should Get Tested?**

Your provider may be more likely to order a flu test if you have symptoms and a high risk of developing a serious illness from the flu and other respiratory infections. Testing helps your provider make sure you get the right treatment to lower your risk.

**High-Risk Groups**

The risk of developing serious complications from the flu is higher for people who:

* Are age 65 and older
* Are younger than age 5 (especially those younger than 2 years old)
* Have a chronic health condition, such as asthma, blood disorders, diabetes, lung diseases, metabolic disorders, obesity, conditions that affect the heart, kidneys, liver, or nervous system, and diseases that weaken the immune system

---

**Flu (Influenza) Test: MedlinePlus Medical Test**

**Category:** health

**What is the flu test?**

The flu test, also known as a flu diagnosis or influenza test, is a medical test used to determine if you have the seasonal flu. The test can help your healthcare provider decide what to do next, such as starting antiviral medicine, and taking steps to lower your chances of spreading the virus to others.

**Who needs a flu test?**

You may need a flu test if you have symptoms of the flu and are at high risk of developing serious complications from the flu. This includes people with conditions such as asthma, blood disorders, diabetes, lung diseases, metabolic disorders, obesity, and diseases that weaken the immune system.

**What happens during a flu test?**

There are two types of flu tests: rapid antigen tests and self-collection tests. Rapid antigen tests usually involve swabbing your nose to collect a fluid sample, which is then tested for signs of influenza A or B virus. Self-collection tests also involve swabbing your nose, but some may use saliva instead.

**Are there any risks to the test?**

Yes, you may feel a gagging sensation or even a tickle if your throat or nose is swabbed. A nasal aspirate or wash may also feel uncomfortable. These effects are temporary.

**What do the results mean?**

The results of your flu test will tell you if signs of influenza A or B virus were found in your sample. Your results are usually described as "positive" or "negative." A positive result means you most likely have the seasonal flu, while a negative result means you may not have the flu.

**What should I do after getting my flu test results?**

If you have a positive result, it's essential to limit your contact with others to prevent infecting them. You can go back to your usual activities when your symptoms have been improving for at least 24 hours and you haven't had a fever or taken fever-reducing medicine.

**How can I lower my risk of getting the flu?**

To lower your risk of getting the flu, avoid close contact with people who are sick, wash your hands often with soap and water, avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth, and clean frequently touched surfaces. Your best protection against serious illness from the flu is to get a yearly flu vaccine (flu shot).

---

**Flu (Influenza) Test**

If you're looking to get tested for the flu, there are several options available. In this article, we'll explore the different types of tests, their accuracy, and what to expect during the testing process.

**Who Should Get Tested?**

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that anyone 6 months or older get vaccinated against the flu each year. Additionally, if you're experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, or fatigue, you should consider getting tested for the flu.

**Types of Flu Tests**

There are several types of tests available to diagnose the flu, including:

* Rapid influenza diagnostic test (RIDT): This is a quick and easy test that can provide results in 15-30 minutes. However, it's not as accurate as other tests.
* Molecular test: This test detects the genetic material of the flu virus and is considered more accurate than RIDT.
* Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test: This test amplifies the genetic material of the flu virus to detect its presence.

**Where to Get Tested**

You can get tested for the flu at various healthcare providers, including:

* Primary care physicians
* Urgent care centers
* Emergency rooms

**What to Expect During Testing**

During testing, you'll typically be asked to provide a nasal swab or throat sample. The test will then detect the presence of the flu virus in your body.

**References**

For more information on flu testing, consult the following resources:

* Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
* Cleveland Clinic: Health Library
* FDA: US Food and Drug Administration
* Labcorp
* Mayo Clinic
* Merck Manual Consumer Version
* Testing.com

---

**Flu (Influenza) Test**

\n\n**Testing Options**

*   Annuals.com: A comprehensive resource on respiratory viruses, including influenza.
*   Testing.com: A website providing information on various medical tests, including influenza testing. [https://www.testing.com/influenza-testing/](https://www.testing.com/influenza-testing/)

\n\n**Related Health Topics**

*   **Common Cold**
*   **Flu**
*   **Flu Shot**
*   **Viral Infections**

\n\n**Understanding Your Test Results**

If you're concerned about your test results, consider consulting a healthcare professional for guidance. They can help you make sense of the information and provide personalized advice.

\n\n**Disclaimer**

The information on this site should not be used as a substitute for professional medical care or advice. Contact a health care provider if you have questions about your health.

**Flu Shot**

Get informed about the flu shot and protect yourself from the flu.

**What is the Flu Shot?**

The flu shot is a vaccine that helps prevent the flu. It's made up of killed or inactivated flu viruses, which can't cause illness but still stimulate your immune system to produce antibodies against the flu.

**Types of Flu Shots**

There are several types of flu shots available:

* **Inactivated or Recombinant**: This type of flu shot contains killed or inactivated flu viruses. It's the most common type of flu shot and is suitable for people of all ages.
* **Live, Intranasal**: This type of flu shot contains a weakened live flu virus. It's given as a nasal spray and is suitable for healthy people between 2 and 49 years old.

**Who Should Get the Flu Shot?**

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that everyone 6 months or older get vaccinated against the flu each year. This includes:

* **Children**: Children 6 months to 8 years old should receive two doses of the flu vaccine, with the second dose given at least 28 days after the first dose.
* **Pregnant Women**: Pregnant women should get vaccinated against the flu to protect themselves and their unborn babies.
* **Older Adults**: Older adults (65 years or older) should get vaccinated against the flu to reduce their risk of serious illness.

**Where Can I Get the Flu Shot?**

You can get the flu shot from your healthcare provider, a local health clinic, or a pharmacy that offers flu vaccination services. Make sure to check with your healthcare provider about the availability and cost of the flu shot before getting vaccinated.

**Language Options**

The flu shot is available in multiple languages:

* **English**
* **Spanish (espaol)**
* **Portuguese (portugus)**
* **Polish (polski)**
* **Russian ()**
* **Somali (Af-Soomaali)**
* **Tagalog (Wikang Tagalog)**
* **Thai ()**
* **Turkish (Trke)**

* **Urdu ()**
* **Vietnamese (Ting Vit)**

**Additional Resources**

For more information about the flu shot, visit the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website at [www.cdc.gov](http://www.cdc.gov).

**What You Need to Know About the Flu Shot**

Are you considering getting a flu shot this season? If so, you're likely wondering what's involved and whether it's right for you. In this article, we'll provide an overview of the flu shot, including its benefits, risks, and what to expect during the vaccination process.

**Benefits of the Flu Shot**

The flu shot is designed to protect against the most common strains of influenza virus circulating during a given season. By getting vaccinated, you can reduce your risk of contracting the flu and experiencing its associated symptoms, such as fever, cough, and body aches. Additionally, the flu shot can help prevent serious complications from the flu, particularly for certain groups of people, like older adults and young children.

**Risks and Side Effects**

While generally safe, the flu shot is not without risks and side effects. Common reactions include:

* Pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site
* Fatigue
* Headache
* Muscle or joint pain

In rare cases, more serious side effects can occur, such as allergic reactions or Guillain-Barr Syndrome (GBS). However, these risks are extremely low and typically outweighed by the benefits of getting vaccinated.

**What to Expect During the Vaccination Process**

When you arrive for your flu shot appointment, you'll typically be asked to provide some basic information about your medical history and any allergies you may have. The vaccination itself is usually quick and painless, with most people experiencing only minor discomfort at the injection site.

After receiving the flu shot, you may be asked to wait for a few minutes to ensure that you don't experience any adverse reactions. Once cleared, you can resume your normal activities without worrying about the flu.

**Language Options**

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) offers flu shot information in multiple languages, including English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Arabic, Hebrew, Hindi, Polish, Vietnamese, and many others. This ensures that individuals from diverse backgrounds can access accurate and reliable information about the flu shot.

**Conclusion**

Getting a flu shot is an important step in protecting yourself against the flu and its associated risks. While there are some potential risks and side effects to consider, these are generally mild and temporary. By staying informed and taking advantage of language options available, you can make an educated decision about whether the flu shot is right for you.

**Additional Resources**

For more information about the flu shot, including language-specific resources, please visit the CDC's website at [www.cdc.gov](http://www.cdc.gov).

title: Flu Shot | Flu | Influenza | MedlinePlus
content:
**Flu Shot**

Also called: Flu vaccine

**What is the flu?**

The flu (influenza) is a respiratory infection caused by influenza viruses that infect your nose, throat, and lungs. These viruses can spread from person to person.

Most people with the flu get better on their own, without medical care. But for some people, the flu is serious. It can cause complications and sometimes even death. People who are 65 and older, under age 5, pregnant, or have certain health conditions are at higher risk of flu complications.

**Benefits of getting a flu shot**

There are many reasons to get a flu shot each year:

*   It may keep you from getting sick with the flu.
*   If you do get the flu, it may be less severe. You may also be less likely to have complications or need to be hospitalized with the flu.
*   If you have certain chronic health conditions, getting a flu shot may help prevent the flu from making your condition worse.
*   Getting the vaccine during pregnancy not only helps protect you from the flu during and after pregnancy. It also helps protect your baby from flu during their first few months of life.
*   It has been shown to lower the risk of severe life-threatening flu in children.
*   It may also protect the people around you, including those who are at higher risk of complications.

**How do flu shots work?**

The flu vaccine causes your immune system to make antibodies about two weeks after you get the shot. These antibodies provide protection against infection with the flu viruses that are in the vaccine.

**Who needs a flu shot?**

The U.S Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends annual flu shots for everyone 6 months and older, with a few rare exceptions.

Flu shots are especially important for people who are at high risk of developing serious complications from the flu.

There are different types of flu vaccines. There are injectable vaccines (shots) and nasal spray vaccines. There are also some vaccines especially for people 65 and older. Ask your health care provider which one is right for you.

**Who should not get a flu shot?**

There are some people who should not get a flu shot:

*   Children younger than 6 months of age.
*   Have severe, life-threatening allergies to flu vaccine or any ingredient in the vaccine. This might include gelatin, antibiotics, or other ingredients.

Some people need to talk to their provider before they get a flu shot. They include people who:

*   Have an allergy to any of the ingredients in the vaccine.
*   Have ever had Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS). Some people with a history of GBS should not get a flu vaccine.

If you are moderately or severely ill, you usually need to wait until you recover before getting a flu shot.

**Why do I need a flu shot every year?**

You need to get a flu shot every year because:

*   Your immune protection from the vaccine declines over time. You need to get the shot every year to boost that protection.
*   Flu viruses are constantly changing, so every year, the flu vaccine is updated. The flu vaccine will include protection against the viruses that will most likely be common during the upcoming flu season.

**When should I get the flu shot?**

For most people who need only one dose of the flu vaccine for the season, September and October are usually good times to get it. It's best to be vaccinated by the end of October.

Some children need two doses of the flu vaccine. They should get their first dose as soon as the vaccine is available. They need to get the second dose at least four weeks after the first.

If you are pregnant, talk to your provider about when to get the vaccine. When you should get it can vary, based on how far along you are in your pregnancy.

**Do flu shots cause side effects?**

Flu vaccines have been shown to be safe. But like any medical product, they can cause side effects. If you have any side effects, they are usually mild and go away on their own within a few days. Common side effects include:

*   Soreness, redness, and/or swelling from the shot
*   Headache
*   Fever
*   Nausea
*   Muscle aches

The flu shot, like other injections, can occasionally cause fainting. In rare cases, some people have a serious allergic reaction.

For most people who need only one dose of the flu vaccine for the season, September and October are usually good times to get it. It's best to be vaccinated by the end of October.

Some children need two doses of the flu vaccine. They should get their first dose as soon as the vaccine is available. They need to get the second dose at least four weeks after the first.

If you are pregnant, talk to your provider about when to get the vaccine. When you should get it can vary, based on how far along you are in your pregnancy.

\n\n

**Do Flu Shots Cause Side Effects?**

Flu vaccines have been shown to be safe. But like any medical product, they can cause side effects. If you have any side effects, they are usually mild and go away on their own within a few days. Common side effects include:

*   Soreness, redness, and/or swelling from the shot
*   Headache
*   Fever
*   Nausea
*   Muscle aches

The flu shot, like other injections, can occasionally cause fainting. In rare cases, some people have a serious allergic reaction.

**Benefits of the Flu Vaccine**

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) states that getting vaccinated against influenza is one of the most effective ways to prevent the spread of the disease. The flu vaccine has been shown to be highly effective in preventing seasonal flu illness.

**Flu Vaccine Safety**

According to the CDC, the flu vaccine is safe for most people. However, as with any vaccine, there are some potential side effects and risks associated with getting vaccinated against influenza. These include:

* Mild side effects such as soreness, redness, or swelling at the injection site
* Fever
* Headache
* Fatigue
* Muscle or joint pain

**Flu Vaccine Guidance for Patients with Immune Deficiency**

The American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (AAAAI) provides guidance on flu vaccine administration for patients with immune deficiency. According to the AAAAI, individuals with weakened immune systems should receive the flu vaccine as soon as it becomes available.

**Flu Vaccine and People with Egg Allergies**

The CDC states that people with egg allergies can still get vaccinated against influenza. However, they recommend that individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to eggs consult with their healthcare provider before getting vaccinated.

**Children**

According to the Nemours Foundation, children can receive a COVID-19 vaccine, flu vaccine, and RSV shot at the same time. However, it is essential to consult with a healthcare provider before administering multiple vaccines simultaneously.

**Women**

The CDC provides information on flu vaccine safety during pregnancy. According to the CDC, the flu vaccine is safe for pregnant women and can help protect them against influenza.
